content: He deploy the microservices without any test.

<response><enhancement>He deployed the microservices without any tests.</enhancement><expert-answer>Use the past tense 'deployed' and the plural form 'tests' when referring to multiple validations. Example: 'She deployed the API after running unit tests.'</expert-answer><continue>What kind of testing strategy do you usually follow before deployment?</continue></response>
We need more better pipeline for automatization.

<response><enhancement>We need a better pipeline for automation.</enhancement><expert-answer>'More better' is redundant. Use 'better' alone, and 'automation' is the correct noun. Example: 'They implemented a better automation pipeline for CI/CD.'</expert-answer><continue>Are you using Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or another tool for automation?</continue></response>
My team are working in AWS project.

<response><enhancement>My team is working on an AWS project.</enhancement><expert-answer>'Team' is a singular collective noun, and we use 'on' with 'working on a project'. Example: 'Our team is working on a serverless AWS app.'</expert-answer><continue>What services are you using in your AWS project so far?</continue></response>
I has created a docker image for backend.

<response><enhancement>I have created a Docker image for the backend.</enhancement><expert-answer>Use 'have' with 'I', and add 'the' before 'backend' if referring to a specific component. Example: 'I have created a Docker image for the frontend service.'</expert-answer><continue>Nice! Did you push the image to Docker Hub or a private registry?</continue></response>
The model don't give accurate predictions.

<response><enhancement>The model doesn't give accurate predictions.</enhancement><expert-answer>For third-person singular, use 'doesn't' instead of 'don't'. Example: 'The classifier doesn't perform well on new data.'</expert-answer><continue>What kind of model are you using, and what are you trying to predict?</continue></response>
Can you explain how work Kubernetes services?

<response><enhancement>Can you explain how Kubernetes services work?</enhancement><expert-answer>The correct order is 'how [subject] [verb]'. Example: 'Can you explain how load balancers work in Kubernetes?'</expert-answer><continue>Are you using ClusterIP, NodePort, or LoadBalancer type services?</continue></response>
I schedule the meeting at yesterday morning.

<response><enhancement>I scheduled the meeting yesterday morning.</enhancement><expert-answer>Use past tense 'scheduled' and avoid 'at' with specific times like 'yesterday morning'. Example: 'I scheduled it yesterday afternoon.'</expert-answer><continue>Did the meeting go as planned, or were there any issues?</continue></response>
Our sprint was delay because blocker issue.

<response><enhancement>Our sprint was delayed because of a blocker issue.</enhancement><expert-answer>Use 'delayed' for past passive voice, and 'because of' requires a noun. Example: 'The release was delayed because of a critical bug.'</expert-answer><continue>What was the blocker, and how did your team resolve it?</continue></response>
She give me the script to run the migration.

<response><enhancement>She gave me the script to run the migration.</enhancement><expert-answer>'Gave' is the correct past tense of 'give'. Example: 'He gave me a shell script to automate the process.'</expert-answer><continue>Was the migration successful, or did you run into any problems?</continue></response>
This API don't support multiple calls at once.

<response><enhancement>This API doesn't support multiple calls at once.</enhancement><expert-answer>Use 'doesn't' with singular subjects like 'API'. Example: 'This endpoint doesnâ€™t allow concurrent requests.'</expert-answer><continue>Are you considering using a queue or batching mechanism to handle that?</continue></response>
